subject: A few more cents
msgSnippet: To Colin Grant: There is a .pdf file for download on the site that explains much about the Read Alphabet.  It s 28 pages long, so it s quite big, but it s a
messageBody:
To Colin Grant: There is a .pdf file for download on the site that
explains much about the Read Alphabet. It's 28 pages long, so it's
quite big, but it's a great tool. Just click "Files,"
then "Resources" and download the QuikScript Manual. Also, go to
http://www.omniglot.com/writing/quikscript.htm to see a table of most
of the characters of Quikscript

In referene to Colin's comments regarding Arabic script: Arabic COULD
theoretically be used for English, but there are letters that do not
fit English, and there lack letters for some English sounds. Also,
the vowel diacritic system would not work, as there are only 3 short
vowels, and 3 long vowels (which are just longer versions of the
short vowels), so it lacks the 15 diacritics that would be required
to write English.

More about my abjad (consonant alphabet, for those of you just
joining us): My abjad is coming along alright, but the characters
resemble Latin letters, and most don't connect quite well. I'm going
to develop soon a cursive version of these letters, so they all
connect, at least most of the time. I'm still working on vowel
indication, and simplifying some of the diacritics. I'll update
anyone that's interested upon request.

To Colin Grant: There is a .pdf file for download on the site that 
explains much about the Read Alphabet.  It's 28 pages long, so it's 
quite big, but it's a great tool.  Just click "Files," 
then "Resources" and download the QuikScript Manual.  Also, go to 
http://www.omniglot.com/writing/quikscript.htm to see a table of most 
of the characters of Quikscript

In referene to Colin's comments regarding Arabic script: Arabic COULD 
theoretically be used for English, but there are letters that do not 
fit English, and there lack letters for some English sounds.  Also, 
the vowel diacritic system would not work, as there are only 3 short 
vowels, and 3 long vowels (which are just longer versions of the 
short vowels), so it lacks the 15 diacritics that would be required 
to write English.

More about my abjad (consonant alphabet, for those of you just 
joining us):  My abjad is coming along alright, but the characters 
resemble Latin letters, and most don't connect quite well.  I'm going 
to develop soon a cursive version of these letters, so they all 
connect, at least most of the time.  I'm still working on vowel 
indication, and simplifying some of the diacritics.  I'll update 
anyone that's interested upon request.
